Answer: You can use DataOutputStream to write byte arrays to a file. Here is an example:

<<<api>>>: DataOutputStream.write
<<<code>>>: 
```java
DataOutputStream out = new DataOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("file.txt"));
byte[] byteArray1 = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
byte[] byteArray2 = {6, 7, 8, 9, 10};
out.writeInt(byteArray1.length); // write the length of the byte array
out.write(byteArray1); // write the byte array
out.writeInt(byteArray2.length); // write the length of the second byte array
out.write(byteArray2); // write the second byte array
out.close();
```
<<<explanation>>>: This code writes the length of each byte array and then the byte array itself to the file. This allows you to read the file back and reconstruct the byte arrays.

To read the file back, you can use a DataInputStream:

```java
DataInputStream in = new DataInputStream(new FileInputStream("file.txt"));
byte[] byteArray1 = new byte[in.readInt()]; // read the length of the byte array
in.readFully(byteArray1); // read the byte array
byte[] byteArray2 = new byte[in.readInt()]; // read the length of the second byte array
in.readFully(byteArray2); // read the second byte array
in.close();
```

This code reads the length of each byte array and then the byte array itself from the file. The readFully method ensures that the entire byte array is read, and if not all bytes are read, it will throw an EOFException.

This approach allows you to write and read multiple variable-length byte arrays to and from a file.
